body:
Apologies for asking but I'm a bit baffled - just added throw new RuntimeException() to one of the existing tests and I can't get the build to fail... it's as onlyIf is set to false somewhere but I can't find it:

```shell
git log -1 --one-line
commit 7a79a3ef0ccd0ab2201674298e9e52ec570d377f (HEAD -> main, origin/main, origin/HEAD)
Author: Sam Brannen <sbrannen@vmware.com>
Date:   Wed Sep 29 10:43:18 2021 +0200
```

```shell
./gradlew cleanTest test --console=plain -p junit-jupiter-engine --info
...
> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:test SKIPPED
Skipping task ':junit-jupiter-engine:test' as task onlyIf is false.
:junit-jupiter-engine:test (Thread[Execution worker for ':' Thread 11,5,main]) completed. Took 0.0 secs.
```

There's obviously something I'm missing but I don't know what it is or where to look. Weird.

> Apologies for asking but I'm a bit baffled - just added throw new RuntimeException() to one of the existing tests and I can't get the build to fail... it's as onlyIf is set to false somewhere but I can't find it:

What exactly are you trying to achieve?

In which module did you modify a test to fail?

What is the result of the Gradle build scan?

Have you tried running with `./gradlew --rerun-tasks test`?

> What exactly are you trying to achieve?

I wanted to implement that extension and added a test. But the test doesn't run. Then I modified another (existing) test - doesn't run either. 

> In which module did you modify a test to fail?

Plain git checkout at de699420216459dd:
gradlew -p junit-jupiter-engine test --rerun-tasks --console=plain

this shows:

```
> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:compileTestJava
> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:compileTestGroovy
> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:testClasses
> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:test SKIPPED

BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 44s
67 actionable tasks: 67 executed
```

Clearly something is wrong... But I've no idea what.

This is the build scan:
https://scans.gradle.com/s/giadc4v5jrxlw

`-p` sets a project property.

So, it looks like what you're trying to do is `./gradlew :junit-jupiter-engine:test`.

You can use `--rerun-tasks` if you really want to make sure that tasks are rerun and not loaded from the cache.

See also: https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#building-from-source

> -p sets a project property.

Large P does it. Small p is a subdirectory directive that narrows tasks. I am not new to Gradle, it is not the source of the problem.

> So, it looks like what you're trying to do is `./gradlew:junit-jupiter-engine:test`.
>
> You can use --rerun-tasks if you really want to make sure that tasks are
> rerun and not loaded from the cache.

I know. But it still doesn't work - see the build scan I posted. This is with rerun tasks and tests still show as skipped.

> See also: https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#building-from-source

I will try on a different machine later. I saw the same behavior on some of the CI jobs you guys have, which is even more confusing.
@dweiss In my relatively inexperienced view, it sounds like the build cache is preventing the task from being re-run? What happens if you disable it with the command-line flag `--no-build-cache`?
Ah, I've just seen the `SKIPPED` in your Gradle logs, which suggests the build cache isn't involved. You can try my suggestion, but I don't know if it'll have any impact.

I had tried several options prior to the build cache - same result, the task always seems to have onlyIf set to false. I'll get to the bottom of this - I just thought I needed some kind of magic switch or environment setup... It is even more weird because I run tons of gradle projects and never saw anything like this. I tend to believe it's one of the plugins playing tricks and disabling tests for some reason but why - I've no idea.

When I execute `./gradlew -p junit-jupiter-engine test --rerun-tasks --console=plain`, I also see that the tests are skipped.

```
> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:compileTestKotlin
w: Language version 1.3 is deprecated and its support will be removed in a future version of Kotlin

> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:compileTestJava
> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:compileTestGroovy
> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:testClasses
> Task :junit-jupiter-engine:test SKIPPED

BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 1m 25s
67 actionable tasks: 67 executed
```

When I execute `./gradlew :junit-jupiter-engine:test --console=plain`, I also see that the tests are skipped.

So, you're right.

Something is wrong!

It appears that ALL tests are SKIPPED across the JUnit 5 repository.

@marcphilipp, could this be because of your recent build refactorings?

### Update

All tests are `SKIPPED` since commit 826088ec6a3b602e0717505233aad9f33205aecc.

I'll create an issue to track this and disable Jacoco support for the time being, so that tests are executed within the build.

issue.title: All tests in Gradle build are SKIPPED

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

As mentioned in https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2733#issuecomment-932747744, all tests in the Gradle build are `SKIPPED` since commit 826088ec6a3b602e0717505233aad9f33205aecc.

I will disable Jacoco support for the time being, so that tests are executed within the build.

## Deliverables

- [x] Determine why all `test` tasks are `SKIPPED` when the Jacoco support is enabled.
- [x] Fix the issue and reinstate Jacoco support.

body:
@dweiss, please pull from `main` and see if tests execute properly for you.

Thanks!
Ha! :) Thank you for looking at this. For a bit I thought I was going crazy. I'll take another look at that patch next week so I'm sure tests will be handy. :)

> Ha! :) Thank you for looking at this. 

You're welcome.

> For a bit I thought I was going crazy. 

For a bit I thought you might be crazy, too.  

I couldn't imagine that a failing test wouldn't fail the build, because that's never happened.

But you were persistent, and we're grateful for that!  

If you hadn't convinced me to investigate it, I would not have made the following change to my last commit... which would _eventually_ have broken the build.

https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/commit/f1cbfbe14a97ff2a3cfa77df48432b180fed83a5#diff-0e90d7805308542bd4864f165cb7fe13c101be5f7f95b5c19a7e4a0cb86e412eR118

Cheers

> For a bit I thought you might be crazy, too. 

Yeah, well. It's still a subject of a heated debate among my children, especially when I ask them to go cycling with me.

Thanks for fixing this, tricky indeed. I'll can go back and try adding that callback later this week.

I haven't had the time, I'm sorry. Preemptive scheduling. I do have this on the list of things to do and I will return to it - it's not a stale issue (if you have spare cycles and wish to take over - please do).
